xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Manuscript received March 30, 2019; revised August 11, 2019 and October 23, 2019; accepted December 12, 2019. Date of publication January 1, 2020; date of current version August 18, 2020. This work was supported in part by the National Key R&D Program of China under Grant 2017YFF0107803, in part by the Key R&D Program of Shandong under Grant 2016ZDJS02A07, and in part by the program for Outstanding Ph.D. candidate of Shandong University. (Corresponding authors: Lelai Zhou; Xincheng Tian.) The authors are with the School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, China (e-mail: aim.cured@gmail. com; sdusyj@gmail.com; txch@sdu.edu.cn; zhoulelai@sdu.edu.cn).

organization.$: School of Control Science and Engineering

affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China

head.citation-title: A Novel Joint Angle Estimation Method for Serial Manipulator Using Micro-Electromechanical Systems Sensors
head.abstracts: Â© 1982-2012 IEEE.This article focuses on the use of low-cost micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) magnetic, angular rate, and gravity (MARG) sensors in the field of estimating the joint angles of revolute serial manipulators. In particular, an easy-to-install joint angle estimation method, named the incremental decomposition method (IDM), is proposed. It allows the MEMS MARG sensors to be mounted in any attitude on any position of the manipulator's links, with at least one attitude measurement unit on the output side of each joint. The IDM is completely independent from the encoder-based joint angle estimator. Hence, it can work as an assistant fault-detection criterion for the economical robotic arms. A robotic arm with six degrees of freedom is used as the experimental setup. The IDM can estimate the manipulator's joint angles by fusing the attitude quaternion output by the MARG sensors. To validate the performances and limitations of this method, five experiments have been accomplished in this article. The experimental results are reported in order, in comparison with the high-resolution encoders.

coredata.dc:description: This article focuses on the use of low-cost micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) magnetic, angular rate, and gravity (MARG) sensors in the field of estimating the joint angles of revolute serial manipulators. In particular, an easy-to-install joint angle estimation method, named the incremental decomposition method (IDM), is proposed. It allows the MEMS MARG sensors to be mounted in any attitude on any position of the manipulator's links, with at least one attitude measurement unit on the output side of each joint. The IDM is completely independent from the encoder-based joint angle estimator. Hence, it can work as an assistant fault-detection criterion for the economical robotic arms. A robotic arm with six degrees of freedom is used as the experimental setup. The IDM can estimate the manipulator's joint angles by fusing the attitude quaternion output by the MARG sensors. To validate the performances and limitations of this method, five experiments have been accomplished in this article. The experimental results are reported in order, in comparison with the high-resolution encoders.
coredata.dc:title: A Novel Joint Angle Estimation Method for Serial Manipulator Using Micro-Electromechanical Systems Sensors
coredata.dc:publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
